body:
All,
I have the following observation with gmtselect, using either an area (-R) or polygon (-F) on a file which has x y and a third column which can be mixed as a text string or number. The outcome is that sometimes the text strings are printed as NaN, and this seems to depend on the value in the first line.

The example underneath illustrates this issue. The only difference between the two tests is that I exchanged the first 2 lines, so the results should be identical. The result of test 1 gives me NaN instead of A and C, the result of test 2 is correct.

echo “Test 1”
echo “.5 .5 1” > temp
echo “.25 .25 A” >> temp
echo “1.7 .7 B” >> temp
echo “.7 .7 C” >> temp
gmtselect -R0/1/0/1 temp
Result:
0.5 0.5 1
0.25 0.25 NaN
0.7 0.7 NaN

echo “Test 2”
echo “.25 .25 A” > temp
echo “.5 .5 1” >> temp
echo “1.7 .7 B” >> temp
echo “.7 .7 C” >> temp
gmtselect -R0/1/0/1 temp
Result:
0.25 0.25 A
0.5 0.5 1
0.7 0.7 C

The bug here may be that the t in -i0-1,2t is being ignored.

* Operating system: linux
* GMT version: 6.0 and 6.2

(note: I am wondering if a similar behaviour may appear with grdtrack where one column of the input file may also have a mix)

comments_content.body:
👋 Thanks for opening your first issue here! Please make sure you filled out the template with as much detail as possible. We appreciate that you took the time to contribute!

Please make sure you read our [Contributing Guide](https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) and abide by our [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md).

It should be gmt select temp -i0,1,t but anyway it does not work.  I think we need something like that to work as it is not possible for some gmt modules like select, which is reading record by record, to detect that a later record than the first has in fact trailing text rather than the number field found at first.  With -i0,1,t we would like it to use that knowledge rather than auto-figuring things out like now.
That's what I said in the [forum post](https://forum.generic-mapping-tools.org/t/gmtselect-issue-gmt6-6-2/1808/8), though I thought the syntax should be **-i0,1,2t**

Actually, the way **-i** works it would not be a good place to tell a module that column 3 is text.  This is a job for **-f**2**s** I think (s for string since t is already taken for time), which we currently don't have. If **-f**2**s** were implemented it would mean x and y are whatever they are for this module, but after the 2nd column everything should be considered trailing text.
OK, but then what's the purpose of **-i**_col_**t**?
See https://docs.generic-mapping-tools.org/dev/gmt.html#icols-full for that.  There is no 2t but there is a "column" called t.

OK, while we are taking I have implemented **-f**_col_**s**:

```
gmt select -R0/1/0/1 temp -f2s
0.5	0.5	1
0.25	0.25	A
0.7	0.7	C
```
I did read but the meaning of **t** is not obvious. Specially when it says *you must explicitly add the column t to retain the text.*. Which *column t*?

"which column t" is nonsensical.  **t** refers to the entire trailing text **once it has been ingested into GMT.**  There are _n_ numerical columns (_n_ >= 0) plus optionally some trailing text. In a case like the one posted here, where the users third column cannot reliably be identified as trailing text based on the first column, we flag the third column as start of trailing text via -f2s and then all works consistently.

Sorry, but still far from clear. If one need to use **t** to retain the text why the **-in**? It seems **-in** equals no **t**.
>  Finally, -in will simply read the numerical input and skip any trailing text.

OK, if it is unclear to you I will re-read it and see if I can improve it, but

1. Default action reads the whole record, including trailing text (if the module can use it - i.e., not in surface etc).  You never specify **t** to include trailing text, but you can use -in to skip it entirely.  Would not do you any good in the poster's case since col 3 was identified as data and you end up with those NaNs
2. On output, again trailing text is the default for most/all modules that pass records through (ie.., not block* etc). If you do not want text on output you use -on, and if you want a mix of columns you use t, e.g., -o2,3,t
3. If you have the above case and need to _explicitly_ say trailing text starts with column 2 then you use -f2s.
I may being particularly dumb tonight but when would we use **-it** then?

I think you never use **-it**.  E.g.

```
echo 1 2 3 text | gmt convert -it
gmtconvert [ERROR]: Selection -it (just trailing text, no numerical input) is not allowed.  Consider using -ot instead, if available.
```

However, you _do_ use it if you select columns and want to include the trailing text:

```
echo 1 2 3 text | gmt convert -i2,1,t
3	2	text
```

versus

```
echo 1 2 3 text | gmt convert -i2,1  
3	2
```

Ah, finally got it. So instead of  
> used you must explicitly add the column t to retain the text

say something like:

> used you must explicitly add the t modifier to always retain the text on output
OK, I can fix that.
Thanks for the swift response and actions! Impressive (as usual).
(Note: the same issue occurs with grdtrack)
grdtrack uses the same -i, -f, -o as any other modules.  This is after the update?  What is the symptoms?

No, this is an observation before the updates, an example underneath. Also the column appear different

#!/bin/sh

gmtswitch gmt6

gmt grdmath -V -I.01 -R0/1/0/1 1 = test.grd

echo "0.1 0.1 A" > temp
echo ".7 .7 1" >> temp
echo "0.1 0.1 A" >> temp
echo "0.5 0.5 B" >> temp
gmt grdtrack temp -Gtest.grd
Result:
0.1          0.1          1              A
0.7          0.7          1              1
0.1          0.1          1              A
0.5          0.5          1              B

echo ".7 .7 1" > temp
echo "0.1 0.1 A" >> temp
echo "0.5 0.5 B" >> temp
gmt grdtrack temp -Gtest.grd
Result:
0.7          0.7          1              1
0.1          0.1          NaN       1
0.5          0.5          NaN       1

Maarten


From: Paul Wessel ***@***.***>
Sent: 21 June 2021 19:48
To: GenericMappingTools/gmt ***@***.***>
Cc: Maarten Vanneste ***@***.***>; Author ***@***.***>
Subject: Re: [GenericMappingTools/gmt] gmtselect issue (gmt6) (#5368)


grdtrack uses the same -i, -f, -o as any other modules. This is after the update? What is the symptoms?

—

Works fine for me with master and the updates.

title: gmtselect issue (gmt6)
